title: Who could be the next men’s Grand Tour winner outside the Big Four?
content:
Cyclist
Who could be the next men’s Grand Tour winner outside the Big Four?

The ‘Big Four’ of Tadej Pogačar, Jonas Vingegaard, Primož Roglič and Remco Evenepoel are undoubtedly the cream of the Grand Tour crop right now. They’ve won a combined 12 three-week races between them, and filled a load of podium spots besides. As such, their names are always the first to go on any predictions lists for further success.

But who are the riders waiting in the wings with the potential to break that stranglehold and add their own name to the illustrious list of Grand Tour champions? We look at six likely candidates.

1. João Almeida (UAE Team Emirates XRG)

João Almeida is 26 years old yet commands the UAE Team Emirates XRG train in Grand Tours with an authority far beyond his years, whether it’s setting up Pogačar for stage wins or corralling Juan Ayuso up the Col du Galibier.

He’s more than comfortable in stage races and formed a dynamic tag-team with Adam Yates at the Tour de Suisse last year, with the pair splitting the stages between them and Yates leading leading home a GC 1-2.

While Pogačar is understandably the team’s number one option right now when it comes to chasing Grand Tour wins, Almeida has been teetering on the edge of a breakthrough success himself since the 2020 Giro d’Italia. Making his Grand Tour debut, he wore the leader’s pink jersey for 15 days and ended up finishing just off the podium. He would go on to place third overall in the 2023 Giro and finished fourth at the Tour de France last year. In all Grand Tours he has completed to date, he has never finished lower than ninth.

But how does the team balance the ambition of Pogačar, the engine of Almeida and the rise of Juan Ayuso? Almeida could move to a different team to achieve his Grand Tour ambitions, but for now that looks unlikely given the rewards he’ll receive for his loyalty at UAE. He’ll be riding in support of Pogačar at the Tour and Vuelta this season, forgoing his own chance once again barring disaster. All eyes on 2026.

2. Juan Ayuso (UAE Team Emirates XRG)

Already a contender at stage races with a win at Itzulia Basque Country and second places at the likes of Tirreno-Adriatico and the Tour de Suisse, Juan Ayuso’s stock continues to rise as he gains more opportunities to shine.

He came third at the 2022 Vuelta a España aged just 19, finishing behind Evenepoel and Enric Mas but ahead of Almeida, but despite finishing fourth at the Vuelta a year later, his progress has stalled somewhat, and last year he failed to finish the Tour de France, the only Grand Tour he took part in.

Ayuso’s chance is surely coming soon though. The 22-year-old is on co-leadership duties with Adam Yates at his debut Giro d’Italia this season and he’s not hiding his Grand Tour ambitions. Yet with several younger riders on UAE vying for the same spot, he’s one that could look for pastures new in order to lead his own team.

3. Antonio Tiberi (Bahrain Victorious)

Bahrain Victorious’s Antonio Tiberi has emerged as one of the team’s major hopes after his firing from Lidl-Trek. The Italian brought home the white jersey for best young rider at the 2024 Giro d’Italia, where he finished fifth overall and was a consistent presence at the front of the race in the second and third week.

He also won youth classifications at the Tour of the Alps and Tour de Luxembourg, and was wearing the white jersey at the Vuelta before he was forced to abandon.

Still just 23 years of age, Tiberi will be eyeing a podium at the Giro this year to cement his status as Italy’s next Grand Tour hope. And he definitely has a shot.

4. Matteo Jorgenson (Visma-Lease a Bike)

For now, Matteo Jorgenson is happy to take things slow and steady for Visma-Lease a Bike, having turned down an opportunity to lead the squad at this year’s Giro. This after the American won the 2024 Paris-Nice and came second at the Critérium du Dauphiné, just eight seconds behind Roglič.

The 25-year-old told Sporza that he dreams of winning a Grand Tour, but that he has asked the team for ‘time and patience’ with the aim of riding a solid third week at this year’s Tour de France in support of Vingegaard first. He was forced to abandon the 2023 Tour before the final week after a crash, but at last year’s race was able to hop back into the top ten with a strong performance on Isola 2000 on Stage 19.

It’s looking promising that Jorgenson could become the next American to win a Grand Tour, and his best hope for now is to avoid the Pogačar vs Vingegaard showdown at the Tour and instead focus his efforts on the Giro next season – provided Vingegaard doesn’t fancy a shot at the maglia rosa himself, that is.

5. Carlos Rodríguez (Ineos Grenadiers)

Ineos Grenadiers’ biggest stage race hope at present is Carlos Rodríguez. The Spaniard’s 2024 season included what were some of the team’s only highlights in a barren year, winning the final stage and finishing second overall at the Tour of the Basque Country, claiming the overall title at the Tour de Romandie and recovering after a tough start to finish seventh at Tour de France.

Rodríguez had already shown his potential the previous year at the Tour, when he took advantage of Pogačar and Vingegaad’s private battle to descend to a famous stage win in Morzine, going on to finish fifth overall despite a crash-hampered final week.

Having only just turned 24, he should be given the keys to the Ineos kingdom at the Tour and Vuelta this year. The only problem is his schedule is the same as Pogačar and Vingegaard’s.

6. Mattias Skjelmose (Lidl-Trek)

Mattias Skjelmose won the white jersey at the Vuelta a España last year in a race that saw him finish fifth overall. It went down to the wire between Skjelmose, Rodríguez and Red Bull-Bora-Hansgrohe’s Florian Lipowitz but the final individual time-trial worked in the Dane’s favour and he took the jersey by over a minute in Madrid.

Skjelmose wanted to ride the Giro this season but Lidl-Trek have pencilled him in for the Tour instead. It won’t be ideal given the competition and his team’s split support with Jonathan Milan’s sprint hopes, but it will serve as a chance to test his legs again over three weeks against the best in the business. He’s only 24 years old after all.

The post Who could be the next men’s Grand Tour winner outside the Big Four? appeared first on Cyclist.
author: Robyn Davidson | Editorial Assistant
